title.narrative: FY18 Results Framework and Milestone
FY19 Results Framework and Milestones
Delivering Impact at Scale: Strategic Plan 2018-2022

THE OCEAN OBJECTIVE: Through the Ocean Action Agenda 2030 partnership, inspire ambition, mobilize action, and support institutions in a cross-sectoral transition toward achieving SDG 14 and a sustainable Ocean economy that contributes to poverty eradication, sustainable livelihoods, and social inclusion.

description.narrative: Develop a common, evidence-based narrative and recommendations on how to create a transformational, sustainable new Ocean economy. Catalyze and accelerate Ocean action by building and supporting public-and private-sector coalitions and connecting existing efforts. Ensure accountability and coherence by monitoring progress against commitments, identifying gaps needing urgent attention, and helping create coalitions that can address these.

title.narrative: By 2020, four of the SDG 14 targets mature, with support from WRI.

description.narrative: Indicator: WRI helps catalyze on-the-ground and transformative action to address plastic pollution in multiple countries.

title.narrative: By 2020, four of the SDG 14 targets mature, with support from WRI.

description.narrative: Indicator: Pacific Rim countries ratify the Port State Measures Agreement to seek to end illegal fishing in the Pacific.

title.narrative: By 2020, four of the SDG 14 targets mature, with support from WRI.

description.narrative: Indicator: Countries reach their marine protected area commitments to designate 10% of national waters as protected by 2020 under SDG 14 and the Aichi target under the Convention on Biological Diversity.

title.narrative: By 2020, four of the SDG 14 targets mature, with support from WRI.

description.narrative: Indicator: Significant progress has been made at the World Trade Organization to end harmful fisheries subsidies.

title.narrative: By 2020, nations launch a process of developing NDOCs (Nationally Determined Ocean Commitments) and countries formally announce their NDOCs by the 3rdUN Ocean Conference in 2023, supported by WRI.

Countries and companies introduce or strengthen ocean economic policies that embrace the principles of a sustainable Ocean economy and seek along-term, vibrant and healthy Ocean, and healthy population, and ensure that the 2030 SDG 14 targets are met.

Countries and companies make more timely adjustments to policies and strategies in hotspots where progress is lacking, enabled by improved monitoring of progress toward SDG 14 through better and more integrated monitoring of biophysical status and trends, and assessment of follow-through on the commitments being made to tackle Ocean issues / developments in policy/program actions through resources including Ocean Watch.

Solutions such as new technologies to tackle marine plastic pollution, technologies that advance transparency about what is happening to the Ocean (and by whom and where), new models for helping deliver protein needs for 10 billion people by 2050 via the sea, and innovative policy frameworks (e.g., next generation marine protected areas) are scaled through existing (and new) networks and consortiums which have been stimulated or formed as a result of WRI’s Ocean Action Agenda 2030 partnership.

The Friends of Ocean Action catalyzes new finance, technology, and additional resources into priority action areas which catalyze and expand theapplication of multi-actor partnerships, financial innovations, and new technologies to help meet SDG 14.

Voluntary commitments (~1400 to date) for action to advance implementation of SDG 14 made by governments, the United Nations system, civil society organizations, academia, the scientific community, and the private sector are accelerated in part by WRI setting up a process for monitoring implementation of the commitments and applying soft pressure via transparency on the commitments.
The global discourse on the Ocean shifts from a focus on the trade-offs between economic growth and ocean protection, toward an understanding that the two can –and must –go together.

description.narrative: Indicator: Number of heads of state making this argument.

title.narrative: FOOD OBJECTIVE: Catalyze reductions of food loss and waste, shifts in diets, and restoration of agricultural lands to help sustainably feed a growing global population.

description.narrative: Get countries and companies to use WRI Food Loss & Waste Protocol and urge policy and practice changes through a high‐level group of champions. Encourage more sustainable diets. Restore yields on degraded lands through mapping restoration opportunities, helping put enabling conditions in place, and convening continent‐wide public-private partnerships on restoration.

title.narrative: Governments in tropical countries commit to restore millions of hectares of degraded agricultural land to agricultural productivity, and restoration‐related policies, practices, and investments in restoration are actively in place for some of these lands.

description.narrative: Indicator: Number of hectares of the above land having supporting policies, practices, and/or investments in place.

title.narrative: Governments in tropical countries commit to restore millions of hectares of degraded agricultural land to agricultural productivity, and restoration‐related policies, practices, and investments in restoration are actively in place for some of these lands.

title.narrative: WRI innovations to help shift diets, including new product formulations and improved marketing language, result in a shift away from beef consumption in the U.S., Europe, and selected emerging economies (e.g., China and Mexico).

description.narrative: Indicator: Percentage of market share, within each target sector in each geography, in which the innovations are adopted.

title.narrative: CLIMATE OBJECTIVE: Incentivize and support actions that increase ambition to reduce global emissions and enhance resilience to climate impacts.

description.narrative: Help countries – with active engagement from other stakeholders – understand where there is greatest potential for progressively increasing climate action in their NDCs, in ways that are aligned with development objectives. Help build up a dynamic and robust international regime that creates transparent rules of the game and fosters ever greater ambition from countries and non‐state actors.

title.narrative: By 2020, the UNFCCC finalizes effective rules and processes for the Paris Agreement that advance transparency and accountability and create a clear process and pathway to assess and increase climate action and support. The full details of some rules and processes will be set by 2019. By 2022, those rules and processes are in full operation.

title.narrative: Publish working paper on gender equity in compensation and resettlement related to large‐scale land acquisitions of community lands in Tanzania and Mozambique.

description.narrative: Achieved – 5 On track – 4 Off track (behind schedule) – 3 Off track (serious setback) – 2 Changed - 1 Not started - 0

comment.narrative: Achieved. Tanzania and Mozambique — countries of vast mountain ranges and open stretches of plateaus — now face a growing land problem. As soil degradation, climate change and population growth place enormous strains on the natural resources that sustain millions of people, multinational companies are also gunning for large swaths of land across both countries. Caught between these pressures, many poor, rural communities get displaced or decide to sell their collectively held land. While they almost always get the short end of the stick in commercial land deals, women struggle more than men to rebuild their lives and livelihoods when villages resettle. A Fair Share for Women: Toward More Equitable Land Compensation and Resettlement in Tanzania and Mozambique finds that, despite constitutional commitments to gender equality, governments in Tanzania and Mozambique are not protecting poor, rural women from harmful commercial land deals. State officials’ failure to close gaps in land laws and overhaul ineffective regulations shortchanges women who receive little to no payment for their families’ land. Attempts to amplify women’s voices in community land decision-making are also falling short. But advancing women’s land rights, from equal treatment in commercial land deals to better representation in community decision-making, is critical to achieving gender equality not just in Tanzania and Mozambique, but also in countries across Africa. This working paper provides recommendations that government officials, private sector leads and civil society can adopt to improve gender equity in commercial land acquisitions. http://www.wri.org/publication/a-fair-share-for-women

title.narrative: FOOD/FORESTS OUTCOME: Governments in tropical countries commit to restore millions of hectares of degraded agricultural land to agricultural productivity, and restoration‐related policies, practices, and investments in restoration are actively in place for some of these lands. A restoration movement is underway, galvanizing millions of people to take action to restore degraded lands and transforming restoration activities into a viable industry.

title.narrative: OCEAN OUTCOME: The global discourse on the Ocean shifts from a focus on the trade-offs between economic growth and ocean protection, toward an understanding that the two can –and must –go together. By 2020, four of the SDG 14 targets mature, with support from WRI: o Significant progress has been made at the World Trade o Organization to end harmful fisheries subsidies. Pacific Rim countries ratify the Port State Measures Agreement to seek to end illegal fishing in the Pacific [target: 11+ additional countries]. o WRI helps catalyze on-the-ground and transformative action to address plastic pollution in multiple countries [target 6+]. o Countries reach their marine protected area commitments to designate 10% of national waters as protected by 2020 under SDG 14 and the Aichi target under the Convention on Biological Diversity. By 2020, nations launch a process of developing NDOCs (Nationally Determined Ocean Commitments) and countries formally announce their NDOCs by the 3rdUN Ocean Conference in 2023, supported by WRI. Countries and companies introduce or strengthen ocean economic policies that embrace the principles of a sustainable Ocean economy and seek along-term, vibrant and healthy Ocean, and healthy population, and ensure that the 2030 SDG 14 targets are met. The Friends of Ocean Action catalyzes new finance, technology, and additional resources into priority action areas which catalyze and expand theapplication of multi-actor partnerships, financial innovations, and new technologies to help meet SDG 14. Solutions such as new technologies to tackle marine plastic pollution, technologies that advance transparency about what is happening to the Ocean (and by whom and where), new models for helping deliver protein needs for 10 billion people by 2050 via the sea, and innovative policy frameworks (e.g., next generation marine protected areas) are scaled through existing (and new) networks and consortiums which have been stimulated or formed as a result of WRI’s Ocean Action Agenda 2030 partnership. Countries and companies make more timely adjustments to policies and strategies in hotspots where progress is lacking, enabled by improved monitoring of progress toward SDG 14 through better and more integrated monitoring of biophysical status and trends, and assessment of follow-through on the commitments being made to tackle Ocean issues / developments in policy/program actions through resources including Ocean Watch. Voluntary commitments (~1400 to date) for action to advance implementation of SDG 14 made by governments, the United Nations system, civil society organizations, academia, the scientific community, and the private sector are accelerated in part by WRI setting up a process for monitoring implementation of the commitments and applying soft pressure via transparency on the commitments.
